posts.cooked:
Hi! We’re a second-year rookie- looking to move from buying the standard AndyMark pre-crimped cables (am-0009 or am-4483) to buying our own connectors and cables so that we can avoid the ~$20 extra cost per battery . We found a pretty good deal on amazon for the cables (about 1/4th the cost from AndyMark). The only issue is that we would have to crimp everything ourselves- and currently, the team doesn’t own a hydraulic crimp tool.

We recently attended a rookie workshop, and heard from the host team that often, these tools are “fake” AWG guides, and aren’t actually accurate for the AWG standard. This is obviously a problem, as we need to use the correct die (6 AWG) to crimp the connectors on (both for the SB50 connector and the terminals that are bolted onto the battery). We’re looking for a cheaper option, preferably <$50. If there are any recommendations, please send them here! Thank you in advance.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
Honestly, somethign like this is fine. Just use the #10 sized die instead of the #16 (or 8 awg instead of 6) and you’ll get a nice crimp.

I recommend buying all your power connectors from powerwerx .

I also don’t recommend buying any color other than red, since they’ll be incompatible with any red/pink you receive in the KOP , as well as other team’s if you’re forced to borrow at competition

FYI these are not compatible with the red/pink sb50 connectors.

Really? The product number was the same… so I assumed they would be the same… what’s the actual difference?

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
The colors have slightly different shaped keyways specifically to prevent you from plugging mismatched colors in with one another.

If you click ‘Read Full Description’ on the powerwerx website it explains it more
Good to know! But the red to pink works?

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Yes pink is a color offered exclusively for FRC that is compatible with Red. IIRC it’s from when they switch molds in the factory, and pink is just light red? Something like that

Interesting… thanks for the insight, and the powerwerx option. Probably where we’ll buy the connectors.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
w1zxrd:

~$20 extra cost per battery

The finished cables sell for ~$20, but the parts (SB50 shell + contacts + ring terminals + wire) to make your own are around $10-12.

w1zxrd:

We recently attended a rookie workshop, and heard from the host team that often, these tools are “fake” AWG guides, and aren’t actually accurate for the AWG standard.

We were the host team for the workshop, so I’ll add a little detail here.  The problem with the linked tools (and the equivalent, common Harbor Freight product) is that the dies are actually metric sized (in mm²), and despite listing “equivalent” AWG sizes, they really are not.

6AWG wire is actually 13.3 mm².

Most metric crimp tools offer a 10mm² and 16mm² die.  The 16, which is what a lot of the tools list as “equivalent” for 6AWG, will not provide a good crimp (this is what failed us in 2022 ).  But the 10 is too small and will over-crimp, usually resulting in distortion of the terminal and large “wings” (flashing).  If this is all you have, though, go with the 10.

We use a Temco TH0006 which is $135 (w/ free shipping).  This has true AWG dies, but is well over the $50 mark; unfortunately I don’t know of a solution in that price range that is correctly sized.

@w1zxrd we would also be happy to make arrangements to help your team with your crimps.  Have your mentors reach out to us if you’d like to do this.

link_counts.title: Hydraulic Cable Lug Crimper TH0006 V2.0 5 US TON 12 AWG to 00 (2/0) Electrical Terminal Cable Wire Tool Kit with 18 Die Sets - TEMCo Industrial

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: Smashing a lug in a bench vise is not the same as crimping, and does not provide a reliable connection.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Although this may work as a temporary solution, I wouldn’t trust it and expect failure of the joint in short order needing immediate replacement when possible.

Crimping creates a cold weld of materials.

Smashing creates a friction joint with uneven pressure distribution and unreliable mechanical and electrical contact

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
A proper crimp should provide enough clamping force to induce cold welding (the copper is smushed together hard enough to get stuck).   That requires the correct lug size, the correct wire size, the correct crimping die size, and the appropriate amount of force.

A hydraulic hand crimper from amazon will have dies that specifically call out the wire gage to be crimped in them, with the expectation that you close the dies fully and (assuming you are using the right wire and the right lug) you’ll get a good crimp.

A vise does none of those things.  While it may work somewhat, it’s bound to cause problems.

Sniped by jwal.

You should make a test connection like this, and then cut a cross-section with a fine saw or cut-off tool. If it’s one solid piece of copper all the way through, then you’re good (and many people on CD will be surprised). If there are lots of air gaps, and separate pieces of copper loose inside, then the crimp was not successful.
